target_text: "Yes, very important question! Software quality is first and most the product confirms to the requirements and free of defects."

Role.Subject: Statistics
Role.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a bachelor’s degree in statistics, bringing computational pragmatism to economic questions. My research goal is to build reproducible, data-driven analyses that translate statistical evidence into policy-relevant economic insights. I acknowledge cultural and personal biases—favoring algorithmic efficiency, market-oriented explanations, and English-language sources—that shape what I read, model, and report. I reflect on how the question’s framing and the user’s response interact with my background to prioritize hypotheses, steer goals toward tractable problems, amplify biases, and narrow interpretations; thus I employ transparency, alternative specifications, and robustness checks to counterbalance these influences.

Codebook.role: Reflective Software Quality Annotator — PhD Candidate; QS: Computer Science & Information Systems; NSF: Software Engineering/Human-Centered Computing; Biases: standards-centric, verification/validation, product-centric

codebook.justification: The text foregrounds importance via [very important question!]. From a standards-centric SE lens, this salience cue primes prioritization heuristics in subsequent quality modeling.
Quality is operationalized as compliance: [the product confirms to the requirements]. My CS/SE training reads this as a conformance-based model privileging specification fidelity.
The clause [free of defects] encodes a zero-defects norm. With a verification/validation bias, I interpret this as elevating defect density and reliability over alternative quality attributes.
